quoteFirst: --Chop or couple of eggs, bread, tea, Rest for half an hour, and then a brisk walk or run. If morning exercise has not been heavy, a row, terminating
quoteLast: Dinner at 12 M.--Beef or mutton, broiled; egg-pudding, with currants in it if desired, or other light farinaceous pudding; old ale, one glass; wine, one glass, (port); or ale, two glasses, without wine. Rest for an hour, and then on the river again for a hard row. “Rowing exercise should be taken twice every day.
title:
Practical Training for Running, Walking, Rowing, Wrestling, Boxing, Jumping, and All Kinds of Athletic Feats
Together with tables of proportional measurement for height and weight of men in and out of condition; etc. etc.
author: James, Ed.

quoteFirst: I got a fire kindled, and purchased from a farmer, ham, etc. I made a good breakfast. This man's house contained upwards of fifty wounded French. Our men gave them water.
quoteLast: the 5th and 3rd Divisions who had fought the day before, being the only part of the army engaged, retired. We soon were joined by the cavalry. The enemy followed close after us. The rain began to fall in torrents.
title:
A British Rifle Man
The Journals and Correspondence of Major George Simmons, Rifle Brigade, During the Peninsular War and the Campaign of Waterloo
author: Simmons, George, 1785-1858; Verner, William Willoughby Cole, 1852-1922 [Editor]

quoteFirst: But they were never difficult to please with food, and their usual dish, eaten twice a day,
quoteLast: and again in the evening, consisted usually of butcher meat mixed with rice, potatoes, cloves, nutmeg, and plenty of olive oil. This strangely seasoned mixture was of their own choosing and was:
title: Sahara

quoteLast: , while walking to and fro along the corridor, he looked into my sitting-room and saw the picture hung upon the wall of alcove. The picture entitled "Morning Sun," represented a glorious, but a little mistic, scene of seashore in the early morning with birds thronging.

quoteTime: about eleven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: of the first day of this terrible devastation that the famous Palace Hotel had finally been emptied of its last guest. The rooms throughout were bestrewn with fallen plaster from ceiling and walls, but otherwise, strange to narrate, the structure had suffered but little damage from the earthquake while all around were collapsed and fallen buildings.
title: The Treasure of Hidden Valley
author: Emerson, Willis George, 1856-1918

quoteLast: , on one of these benches placed where rock is steepest and forest trees stand close together and vines are rank with shade, a sociable-looking little fellow of some ten hardy well-buffeted years had sat down for the moment without a companion. He had thrown upon the bench beside him his sun-faded, rain-faded, shapeless cap, uncovering much bronzed hair; and as though by this simple act he had cleared the way for business, he thrust one capable-looking hand deep into one of his pockets.
title: A Cathedral Singer
author: Allen, James Lane, 1849-1925; Ivanowski, Sigismond de, 1875-1944 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The day will be sultry and oppressive, and a fire will be required at night. In the morning,
quoteLast: , the thermometer showed 80° Fahrenheit; at 4 P.M., the sky being clouded over, it fell 25°; before dawn, affected by the cold north wind from the snows about the Pass, it stood at 40°.
title: The City of the Saints, and Across the Rocky Mountains to California
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: [Sidenote: We anchor in Bay Duclos.] We ranged along it, and kept sounding continually; and,
quoteTime: about eleven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , we anchored a mile off shore, in eight fathom and a half, oozy sand, in a bay, which I named Bay Duclos[74]; from the name of M. Duclos Guyot, a captain of a fire-ship, who was the next in command after me on this voyage; and whose knowledge and experience have been of very great use to me.
title: A voyage round the world
author: Bougainville, Louis-Antoine de, comte, 1729-1811; Forster, Johann Reinhold, 1729-1798 [Translator]

quoteFirst: _Wednesday, April 15th._--Weather clear, and light wind from the eastward. Finished coaling ship this morning. At
quoteLast: a couple of whale-boats from two vessels in the offing pulled into the harbour; went on board our prize, and thence to the shore. Although the two masters were told that we were the Iroquois, they seemed at once to have comprehended the true state of the case, and to make haste to put themselves out of harm's way.
title:
The Cruise of the Alabama and the Sumter
From the Private Journals and Other Papers of Commander R. Semmes, C.S.N., and Other Officers
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877

quoteFirst: Pulse 80 at 7 A.M. (his own statement), at 2.30 P.M. pulse 100, temp. 99.4 degrees. Bowels acted at 12 midnight, 3.30 A.M. and
quoteLast: Went that day to have his photograph taken. The throat was better. Tongue dry and leathery. It was plain to me that he was taking too much food.
title:
The Healthy Life, Vol. V, Nos. 24-28
The Independent Health Magazine

quoteFirst: The result is, as may be frequently observed, that the labour-shed is not cleared until
quoteTime: nearly eleven o’clock in the morning
